item.description:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:17, topic:39335”]Yep yep, that’s why the annoying advertisement keeps going even after you’ve blocked all the sites, tried to change it to display:none, type=“hidden”, and other things and even just disabled scripting.

But you don’t need an applet to do that, you can start Java without even having any Java code. And it can read your files without your consent. Here’s an example:

[code]

[/code][/quote] where is that accessing files eh?

also, when you set the source of the iframe to ‘about:blank’, the ads dont refresh. i honestly believe, like usual, that you dont have half a clue what you are talking about

item.title: [Undetectable loader] (Only the loader)
item.dc:creator: @popcorn89 popcorn89
item.description:
@popcorn89 wrote:

[quote=“moparisthebest, post:16, topic:39335”]Actually they do use the netscape package which can communicate with javascript in the same document, I am going to quote myself rather than retype it:

[quote author=moparisthebest link=topic=70856.msg805590#msg805590 date=1169459706]
It is entirely possible through the netscape package included with java. Javascript can call methods and change variables in a java applet, and a java applet can call methods and change variables in javascript provided they are ran on the same page. I found alot of info for this on google not too long ago, I will try to dig up the links for you again.

edit:

http://java.sun.com/products/plugin/1.3/docs/jsobject.html
http://www.codeproject.com/jscript/javatojs.asp?df=100&forumid=736&exp=0&select=119638

I got those from: http://www.google.com/search?q=javascript+communicating+with+applet

Good luck on whatever you are doing.
[/quote][/quote]

The only method that touches the LiveConnect package is ra.a. The three times it’s called the exception is caught and popped. Now that I’m thinking about it, they could call it using reflection, but right now there’s no proof that they do.

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:19, topic:39335”]Using the loader is for nubs, the only thing it ever touches is the UID and those .idx files.

[quote author=moparisthebest link=topic=55301.msg687761#msg687761 date=1167178624]

That would load the runescape applet… This code is for bots… it allows you to modify the classes because they’re going through your own loader… This also makes bots less detectable because your actually using the loader like the normal RS client

Apparently noone realizes that if you use the normal runescape client unsigned you DO NOT use the loader, but simply runescape.jar
[/quote][/quote]

And obviously you know what you’re talking about…

There’s no reason not to use the loader, or even to modify the code at all. You can make a perfectly fine bot without ever changing anything.

Read full topic

item.title: [Undetectable loader] (Only the loader)
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

You clearly didn’t understand what I was saying:

  1. This method is detectable, not because of any of the HTML shit, thats nothing to do with the loader hack, the loader can detect changes to the loader, i’ll say no more, this is classified info

  2. I was just letting moparisthebest know that the loaderhack isn’t solely to provide less detectability, it does infact play a huge role in the bot, allowing substitution of modified classes.

item.title: [Undetectable loader] (Only the loader)
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

Yep yep, that’s why the annoying advertisement keeps going even after you’ve blocked all the sites, tried to change it to display:none, type=“hidden”, and other things and even just disabled scripting.

But you don’t need an applet to do that, you can start Java without even having any Java code. And it can read your files without your consent. Here’s an example:

<html>
<input type="text" size="45" id="tmpl">
<input type="button" id="sWitch" value="show" onclick="toggle();">
<input type="hidden" id="painter" value="paint" onclick="draw();">
<script type="text/javascript">
var S = false;
var T = java.awt.Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit();
var F = new java.awt.Frame();
function toggle(){
   F.setVisible(S = !S);
   painter.type= S ? "button" : "hidden";
   sWitch.value = S ? "hide" : "show";
}
function draw(){
   if(!S) return;
   F.getGraphics().drawImage(T.getImage(tmpl.value),4,30,F.getWidth() + 4,F.getHeight()-4,null);
}
</script>
</html>

Read full topic

item.title: [Undetectable loader] (Only the loader)
item.dc:creator: @popcorn89 popcorn89
item.description:
@popcorn89 wrote:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:11, topic:39335”][quote author=ownagesbot link=topic=55301.msg877726#msg877726 date=1170967232]
Anyway, this is slightly detectable, I don’t know the specifics PSB just lemmie know that his is, which means mine is.[br][size=1]Posted on: January 11, 2007, 11:46:36 AM[/size][hr][quote author=moparisthebest link=topic=55301.msg687761#msg687761 date=1167178624]

That would load the runescape applet… This code is for bots… it allows you to modify the classes because they’re going through your own loader… This also makes bots less detectable because your actually using the loader like the normal RS client

Just to let you know, the loaderhack isn’t solely for undetectability, it’s also used to allow the bot to be able to substitute its own classes in (the classes you used bcel on)

Apparently noone realizes that if you use the normal runescape client unsigned you DO NOT use the loader, but simply runescape.jar
[/quote]
[/quote]

Well of course, the client wont find any DOM elements and then know somethings up. You have to provide it with a fake HTML advertisement to stay busy with.[/quote]
I’m pretty sure the client doesn’t detect that, but it’s a good thought.

Read full topic

item.title: [Undetectable loader] (Only the loader)
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

EDIT: RLN told me that you should make your own peoples, hes a nasty not nice so ignore him and just obide by this:
“This is for learning purposes only and to influence, enhance and optimize your code and/or knowledge on the loader stuff!”
Okay, now RLN has no point

Okay, this is my loader, if it wasn’t for pplsuqbawls this wouldn’t exist so <3 to him.
I did this well over a month(maybe more) ago now, and well its nothing special any more so I thought i’d give you something to play.

This is based totally on pplsuqbawls theory, so all credit to him. Infact this is basically a port from his PBCL (or w/e the fuck its called byte code library), version of the loader hack.

If pplsuqbawls wants me to remove this I will so without argument.

IF you decide to use the theory behind this for you own bot, you MUST credit pplsuqbawls.
IF you decide to use this/a modified version of this you MUST credit me and pplsuqbawls.

They are my only terms. Oh, no ripping what so ever either.

Ok, well ive got so much shit in my bot I cba to post it all, so here is the raw method + the definesub methods, they’ll need modifying seeing as they use my own hashmap etc etc.

If you don’t understand this, don’t know how to use it or know what it is, fuck off we don’t want spam “ho can i use this is this bot” and shit.
However feel free to ask sensible questions and I will answer them best I can.

[code] public Class<?> loadClass(String cName) throws ClassNotFoundException {
Class c = null;
try {
c = super.findSystemClass(cName);
} catch(ClassNotFoundException cnfe) {
try {
ZipEntry zip = loaderJar.getEntry(cName.replaceAll("\.", “/”) + “.class”);
ClassGen cg = new ClassGen(new ClassParser(loaderJar.getInputStream(zip),zip.getName()).parse());
int classidx = ((ConstantClass) cg.getConstantPool().getConstant(cg.getSuperclassNameIndex())).getNameIndex();
ConstantUtf8 utf = ((ConstantUtf8) cg.getConstantPool().getConstantPool().getConstant(classidx));

            if("java/lang/ClassLoader".equals(utf.getBytes())) {
                utf.setBytes("BotClassLoader");
                int count = 0;
                for(Constant con : cg.getConstantPool().getConstantPool().getConstantPool()) {
                    if(con != null) {
                        if(con instanceof ConstantMethodref) {
                            ConstantMethodref cm = (ConstantMethodref) con;
                            ConstantNameAndType cnt = (ConstantNameAndType) cg.getConstantPool().getConstantPool().getConstant(cm.getNameAndTypeIndex());
                            ConstantUtf8 name = ((ConstantUtf8) cg.getConstantPool().getConstantPool().getConstant(cnt.getNameIndex()));
                            if(name.getBytes().equals("defineClass") || name.getBytes().equals("findSystemClass")) {
                                count++;
                                name.setBytes(name.getBytes() + "Sub");
                            }
                            if(count > 1) break;
                        }
                    }
                }
            }
            for(Field f : cg.getFields()) {
		        if (f.getType().equals(new ObjectType("java.applet.Applet"))){
			        cg = injectObject(cg,"java.applet.Applet",f.getName(),"getClient");
			        break;
		        }
            }
            cg.addInterface("interfaces.intLoader");
            byte buffer[] = cg.getJavaClass().getBytes();
             c = defineClass(cName, buffer, 0, buffer.length);
         }  catch (Exception e) {
         e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
    if(c != null) return c;
    return super.loadClass(cName);
 }[/code]

[code]import com.sun.org.apache.bcel.internal.classfile.JavaClass;

public class BotClassLoader extends ClassLoader {
public BotClassLoader() {
}

protected final Class<?> defineClassSub(String name, byte[] b, int off, int len) {
    JavaClass rez = Bot.jcHash.get(name);
    Class c = null;
    if (rez == null) { c = super.defineClass(name, b, off, len); Bot.classes.put(name,c); return c;}
    byte[] bytes = rez.getBytes();
    c = super.defineClass(name, bytes, 0, bytes.length);
    Bot.classes.put(name,c);
    return c;
}

protected final Class<?> findSystemClassSub(String name) throws ClassNotFoundException {
    return super.findSystemClass(name);
}

}[/code]

NOTE: This uses JDK’s bcel package. JDK5 will compile this but is majorly deprecated. I reccommend getting JDK6 or importing your own BCEL package (from the bcel jar off of the bcel svn).

Anyhow enjoy.

Read full topic
